bibl.title: James McGarth and William Herbert v. King County. Request for Writ of Habeas Corpus
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.ab: Territory of Washington Third Judicial District SS In the District Court holding terms at Seattle in King County
In the Matter of the Application of James McGrath and William Herbert Complaintant For a Writ of Habaes Corpus
div1.p: To the Hon. Roger S. Greene Chief Justice of Washington Territory and Judge of the 3rd Judicial District therein
The Complaint of James McGrath and William Herbert respectfully shows:

That the said James McGrath and William Herbert are unlawfully imprisioned detained, confined and restrained of their liberty by LV Wycroff Keeper of the jail of King County Washington Territory, at Seattle in said King County; that your petitioners are confined in the county; that the cause or pretense of the said imprisionment, detention, confinement and restraint is a certain committment issued by one Rosevelt Scott Coles is
or pretends to be a Justice of the Peace in and for said King County said Committment hearing signed by said Scott against the said James McGarth and William Herbert upon an alledged examination before said Scott acting as such Justice of the Peace upon a extended floor change against the said James McGrath and William Herbert charging them with passing counterfit coin of the United States knowing the sames to be counterfit, that said committment was issued on or about March 17th 1880.
That the said imprisionment, confinement, detention, and restraint are illegal; and that the illegality thereof consists in this manner:

1st Because the said Scott acting as a Justice of the Peace had no jurisidiction to examine the said McGarth and Herbert upon the said charge of passing counterfit coin or to committ them upon any such charge.
2nd Because no sufficent compliant was ever made charging the said McGarth and Herbert with the said crime of passing counterfit coin
3rd Because the said McGarth and Herbert were not allowed the benefit of counsel on said examination

4th Because there is no reasonable or probable cause or ground upon which to charge the said McGarth or Herbert or either of them with the crime of passing counterfit coin or or any other offense whatsoever and they are not guilty of any offence whatsoever.

Wherefore the said James McGarth and the said William Herbert pray that a Writ of Habeas Corpus may be granted directed to the said L. V. Wycroff Keeper of the Jail as aforementioned, commanding him to bring the bodies of the said James McGarth and William Herbert before your Honor at a time and place to be
specified to do and recieve what shall then and there be considered by your Honor, concerning said James McGarth and William Herbert together with the true and cause of their detention and said writ and that they the said James McGarth and William Herbert may be restrained to their liberty
div1.ab: Dated March 20th 1880 James McGarth William Herbert

Territory of Washington County of King James McGarth and William Herbert say, each of himself, that he is me of the complaintants, making the frequent complaints, that he has heard the said complaint read, knows the contents thereof and believes the said to be true. James McGarth William Herbert
Subscribed and sworn before me March 20th 1880 J.M. Hall Notary Public

No. 2411 Matter of the Application of James McGarth and William Herbert for Writ of Habeas Corpus Filed March 20th 1880 James Seavy Clerk By James R Ludlow Deputy Clerk Hall and Osborne Attys for Complaints
